questions.text: A physician observed the following finding in a small child who came for an eye exam. This finding is associated with which of the following conditions?  (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Hyperopia

 

Esotropia (convergent squint) is commonly seen in children with hyperopia (also known as hypermetropia).

 

Accommodative esotropia:

 

It occurs due to overaction of convergence associated with accommodation reflex. It is of three types:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Myopia (Short-sightedness):

  • Esotropia: Less common in myopic children.
  • Refractive Error: Light focuses in front of the retina.
  • Symptoms: Difficulty seeing distant objects clearly.

 

Option B. Astigmatism:

  • Effect on Squint: Can cause both esotropia and exotropia depending on the axis and severity of astigmatism.
  • Refractive Error: Light is focused at multiple points due to an irregular corneal shape.
  • Symptoms: Blurred or distorted vision at all distances.

 

Option D. Emmetropia (Normal Vision):

  • Esotropia: Rarely associated.
  • Refractive Error: No significant refractive error; light focuses correctly on the retina.
  • Symptoms: Normal vision without the need for corrective lenses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyperopia is commonly associated with accommodative esotropia in children, where the effort to focus on near objects results in excessive convergence and inward deviation of the eyes. Corrective lenses help to reduce the accommodative effort, thereby alleviating the esotropia.

questions.text: In comparison to Bochdalek hernias, Morgagni hernias are: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Answer: B. Less common

 

Morgagni hernias are congenital diaphragmatic hernias that occur anteriorly through the foramen of Morgagni (space of Larrey), which is located between the sternal and costal attachments of the diaphragm. These hernias are significantly less common than Bochdalek hernias, accounting for only about 2-3% of all congenital diaphragmatic hernias. Unlike Bochdalek hernias, Morgagni hernias are typically smaller in size, tend to be right-sided, and are anterior rather than posterior in location.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Posterior in location - This is incorrect as Morgagni hernias are anterior diaphragmatic hernias. It's actually Bochdalek hernias that occur posterolaterally through the posterolateral defect in the diaphragm.

 

Option C. Larger in size - This is incorrect as Morgagni hernias are typically smaller than Bochdalek hernias. Bochdalek hernias are often large enough to allow significant herniation of abdominal contents into the thoracic cavity.

 

Option D. More frequently left-sided - This is incorrect as Morgagni hernias are more commonly right-sided (90% of cases) or bilateral, whereas Bochdalek hernias are more frequently left-sided (approximately 80-85% of cases).

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Morgagni hernias are less common anterior diaphragmatic hernias that are typically right-sided, in contrast to the more common, left-sided, posterior Bochdalek hernias.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy was brought to the ER with complaints of melena. The child had intermittent pain in the right iliac region. On surgical exploration, the following was found. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Meckel’s diverticulum

 

Explanation:

 

Meckel’s Diverticulum:

 

  • Congenital anomaly resulting from incomplete obliteration of the vitelline duct.
  • Rule of 2’s:
    • Found in 2% of the population.
    • 2 feet from the ileocecal valve.
    • 2 inches long.
    • 2 types of ectopic mucosa (gastric & pancreatic).
    • 2:1 male predominance.
  • Complications:
    • Bleeding (painless hematochezia/melena) due to acid secretion from ectopic gastric mucosa, leading to ulceration.
    • Intestinal obstruction (due to volvulus or intussusception).

    • Diverticulitis, mimicking appendicitis.

       

Other Options:

 

Option B. Obstructed Bowel Loops → Incorrect

 

  • Would present with bilious vomiting, abdominal distension, and absent bowel sounds.
  • No mention of melena or ectopic gastric tissue.

 

Option C. Appendicitis → Incorrect

 

  • While pain is in the right iliac fossa, melena is not a feature of appendicitis.
  • Would present with fever, localized tenderness, rebound tenderness, and leukocytosis.

 

Option D. Appendicular Mucocele → Incorrect

 

  • A mucocele is a mucus-filled dilatation of the appendix, usually seen in adults.
  • Presents as a mass in the right iliac fossa, but not with melena.

 

Educational Objective:

 

It presents with painless lower gastrointestinal bleeding due to ectopic gastric mucosa, mimicking appendicitis. Diagnosis is confirmed by Meckel’s scan, and treatment is surgical resection in symptomatic cases.

questions.text: Identify the investigation shown. (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) PET

 

The image provided shows a comparison between three types of imaging modalities: PET, CT, and PET-CT. PET (Positron Emission Tomography) is a nuclear medicine functional imaging technique used to observe metabolic processes in the body. In this case, the PET scan highlights areas of the body where the radioactive glucose analog 18F-FDG has been absorbed, typically areas with high glucose metabolism such as tumors.

 

The combined PET-CT image integrates the metabolic information from the PET scan with the anatomical detail provided by the CT scan, which allows for precise localization of the metabolic activity within the body's structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. USG: Ultrasound (USG) uses sound waves to create images of the inside of the body. It does not produce the type of image shown in this question.

 

Option B. MRI: Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) uses strong magnetic fields and radio waves to produce detailed images of the body's internal structures. The images from MRI are different from those of PET scans, which focus on metabolic activity.

 

Option D. X-ray: X-rays provide images based on the absorption of X-ray photons by different tissues, primarily used to visualize bone structures. The image shown is not an X-ray, as it does not display the typical bone-focused detail of X-ray imaging.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The investigation shown in the image is a PET scan (and PET-CT), which highlights areas of high metabolic activity, commonly used for detecting cancer.

choices.text: Yeast cells with Pseudohyphae are seen
Severe infection is seen if CD4 count is below 900

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the likely organism shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Most commonly affects lungs

 

The image shows encapsulated yeast cells characteristic of Cryptococcus neoformans. This fungal pathogen primarily affects the lungs, causing pneumonia as its initial manifestation. After infecting the lungs, it can disseminate to other organs, most notably the central nervous system, where it causes meningitis. The lung involvement is typically the first and most common site of infection for Cryptococcus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Yeast cells with Pseudohyphae are seen: Incorrect. Cryptococcus neoformans appears as round yeast cells with a characteristic capsule. It does not form pseudohyphae, which are more commonly associated with Candida species.

 

Option C. Humans are the only reservoir: Incorrect. The main environmental reservoirs for Cryptococcus neoformans are bird droppings (especially pigeons) and certain trees like eucalyptus. Humans are not considered reservoirs for this organism.

 

Option D. Severe infection is seen if CD4 count is below 900: Incorrect. Severe cryptococcal infections are typically seen in immunocompromised individuals, particularly HIV patients with CD4 counts below 200 cells/μL, not 900.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cryptococcus neoformans most commonly affects the lungs as the primary site of infection, followed by potential dissemination to other organs, especially the central nervous system.

questions.text: Repeated Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (rTMS) of the brain has been FDA-approved for the treatment of which of the following conditions? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Depression

 

Explanation: 

 

Repetitive Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (rTMS) has been approved by the FDA for the treatment of major depressive disorder. rTMS uses rapidly changing magnetic fields to produce small electric currents (known as eddy currents) in superficial cortical neurons" and is "approved as a treatment modality in major depressive disorder." It is typically used for patients with depression who have not responded adequately to antidepressant medications.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B. Resistant Schizophrenia (Incorrect): While there is ongoing research into the potential benefits of rTMS for various symptoms of schizophrenia, it is not FDA-approved for the treatment of resistant schizophrenia. Clozapine remains the standard treatment for treatment-resistant schizophrenia.
  • Option C. Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (Incorrect): Deep TMS was approved by the FDA for the treatment of OCD in 2018. At the time this question was written, option C was incorrect; however, as of today, it would also be considered a correct option.
  • Option D. Acute Psychosis (Incorrect): rTMS is not FDA-approved for the treatment of acute psychosis. Antipsychotic medications are the primary treatment for acute psychotic episodes.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Repetitive Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (rTMS) is a non-invasive brain stimulation technique that has the FDA approval for the following psychiatric disorders:

  1. Major Depressive Disorder (MDD) 
  2. Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD) 
  3. Anxious Depression 
  4. Smoking Cessation

questions.text: A woman presents to you with fever, arthralgia, ulcers, fatigue for the past six months, and new-onset hematuria. Urine examination reveals RBC casts and proteinuria. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Lupus nephritis

 

Lupus nephritis is a common complication of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), an autoimmune disease that can affect multiple organ systems. The patient's symptoms of fever, arthralgia, ulcers, and fatigue, combined with new-onset hematuria and findings of RBC casts and proteinuria in the urine, are indicative of systemic involvement typical of lupus nephritis.

 

Lupus nephritis is characterized by inflammation of the kidneys, often leading to hematuria, proteinuria, and renal impairment.

 

Next Step -

 

Conducting an ANA (antinuclear antibody) test.

 

Performing an anti-dsDNA (anti-double stranded DNA) test, which is noted as being very specific and correlates with lupus nephritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute interstitial nephritis: This condition typically presents with WBC casts rather than RBC casts in the urine and is not usually associated with systemic symptoms like fever, arthralgia, or ulcers.

 

Option B. Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN): While PSGN can cause RBC casts and proteinuria, it is generally a renal-limited condition and does not present with systemic symptoms like fever, arthralgia, and ulcers.

 

Option D. IgA nephropathy: IgA nephropathy is also a renal-limited condition and typically does not present with systemic symptoms. It is characterized by recurrent episodes of gross hematuria, usually following upper respiratory infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lupus nephritis should be suspected in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus who present with renal symptoms such as hematuria and proteinuria, especially when accompanied by systemic symptoms like fever, arthralgia, ulcers, and fatigue. Further testing, including ANA and anti-dsDNA antibodies, is warranted to confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with muscle cramps, tingling around her mouth, and a history of hypocalcemia. During the physical examination, tapping on the facial nerve just anterior to the ear elicits twitching of the facial muscles. What is this finding called? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chvostek’s sign

 

Explanation:

 

Chvostek’s sign is a clinical manifestation of hypocalcemia, where tapping the facial nerve anterior to the ear causes ipsilateral facial muscle twitching. This sign indicates neuromuscular irritability due to hypocalcemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trousseau’s sign: Also seen in hypocalcemia, but involves carpopedal spasm induced by inflating a blood pressure cuff above systolic pressure for 3 minutes

 

Option C. Babinski sign: Indicates upper motor neuron lesions, not related to calcium homeostasis

 

Option D. Homan’s sign: Associated with deep vein thrombosis (DVT), not calcium metabolism

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chvostek’s sign is facial muscle twitching elicited by tapping the facial nerve in hypocalcemia, representing neuromuscular irritability.

questions.text: A woman with a history of painful genital ulcers 1 year back has a neonate of 1 week who has lesions on face and body with neurological symptoms. What is the likely infection? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HSV (Herpes Simplex Virus)

 

The question presents a scenario where a woman has a history of painful genital ulcers and has given birth to a neonate who now exhibits lesions on the face and body along with neurological symptoms. This clinical picture strongly suggests a neonatal herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection.

 

  • Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) is known to cause painful genital ulcers in adults. The virus can remain latent in the body and reactivate later. During pregnancy or delivery, HSV can be transmitted to the neonate, particularly during vaginal delivery if there are active lesions or viral shedding. Neonatal HSV infection can present with vesicular lesions on the skin, eyes, and mouth, and it may also involve the central nervous system, leading to neurological symptoms. Neonatal HSV infection is a serious condition that requires prompt antiviral treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Toxoplasma: Incorrect because it does not cause painful genital ulcers in the mother or the described symptoms in the neonate.

 

Option B. Varicella: Incorrect because, although it can cause skin lesions in neonates, it is not linked with a history of painful genital ulcers in the mother.

 

Option D. CMV: Incorrect because CMV can cause congenital infections with neurological symptoms, but it is not associated with painful genital ulcers in the mother.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A history of painful genital ulcers in the mother, especially when associated with neonatal lesions and neurological symptoms, is highly suggestive of neonatal HSV infection. HSV is a serious condition that requires immediate medical attention to prevent severe outcomes in the neonate.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of NAME syndrome? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ebstein's anomaly

 

NAME syndrome is now recognized as part of the Carney complex, which falls under Multiple Endocrine Other Organ Neoplasia (MEON). The NAME acronym stands for:

 

  • N: Nevi (blue nevi – skin manifestation)
  • A: Atrial myxoma
  • M: Myxoid neurofibroma
  • E: Ephelides (freckles)

 

Ebstein's anomaly is not a component of this syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:


NAME syndrome (now part of Carney complex) consists of Nevi (blue), Atrial myxoma, Myxoid neurofibroma, and Ephelides (freckles). Ebstein's anomaly is not a component of this syndrome.

questions.text: Which nerve is most likely affected, based on the hand posture shown in the image? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ulnar nerve

 

  • Claw Hand deformity is a condition where the fingers are bent into a position that looks like a claw. 
  • It may affect all of the fingers or only some of them depending on its cause. 
  • Claw Hand is a hand deformity with hyperextension of the MCP joints and flexion of the IP joints due to weakness of the intrinsic muscles of the hand. 
  • Claw Hand deformity can be complete when it involves all the digits due to both ulnar and median nerve palsy, or it can be incomplete/partial where it involves only ulnar 2 digits due to isolated ulnar nerve palsy.
  • Signs and Symptoms:
    • Muscle wasting of the interrosseous and hypothenar
    • Numbness along the nerve involved
    • Inability to extend the IP joints during extension of the fingers, to abduct and adduct fingers
    • Unopposed action of the extensors and the flexors digitorum profundus as the lumbricals of digits 4 and 5 are paralyzed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Median nerve: Compression, stretch, or traumatic disruption of the nerve may result in median nerve palsies. Most commonly, palsies of the median nerve are caused by compression at the carpal tunnel, known as carpal tunnel syndrome. Women have 3 times higher incidence of carpal tunnel syndrome compared to men. It peaks around age 50 but also frequently present in the older population. Patients with diabetes and thyroid disease are at an increased risk for carpal tunnel syndrome. With carpal tunnel syndrome, weakness in the thenar eminence is observed. Isolation of the opponens pollicis power is done by asking the patient to palmarly abduct the thumb. 

 

Option C. Musculocutaneous nerve: Isolated injuries of the Musculocutaneous Nerve are rare. It may become injured by brachial Plexus damage, compression injury, dislocation of the shoulder, shoulder surgery, or entrapment of the nerve at the elbow. Most significant is the entrapment of the musculocutaneous nerve within the coracobrachialis muscle, leading to biceps brachii and brachialis weakness and atrophy with accompanying loss of sensation in the lateral forearm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image shows Claw hand deformity wherein the MCP joint of the fingers is hyperextended while the IP joint is flexed in the 4th and 5th digits. 
  • This occurs due to weakness of the intrinsic muscles of the hand which are supplied by the ulnar nerve. 
  • Thus, ulnar nerve palsies lead to claw hand deformity.

choices.text: Lower BP in childhood will have high BP in adulthood
Higher BP in childhood will have low BP in adulthood
Lower BP in childhood will have normal BP in adulthood
Lower BP in childhood will have low BP in adulthood

questions.text: According to the tracking phenomenon of blood pressure in the population, it is observed that if BP of a person is tracked from childhood to adulthood, then: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lower BP in childhood will have low BP in adulthood

 

The tracking phenomenon in blood pressure refers to the observation that blood pressure levels in individuals tend to maintain their relative rank over time. This means that a child who has lower blood pressure compared to peers is likely to have relatively lower blood pressure as an adult as well. Similarly, a child with higher blood pressure is likely to have higher blood pressure as an adult. This consistency is why blood pressure is said to "track" like the lanes of a track race, where individuals generally stay in their respective lanes over time.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The tracking phenomenon suggests that individuals with lower BP in childhood are likely to maintain lower BP into adulthood.

questions.text: Artery supplying near marked structure is (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anterior interventricular artery

 

The anterior interventricular artery, also known as the left anterior descending artery (LAD), supplies the anterior portion of the interventricular septum. This artery runs along the anterior interventricular groove and is critical in providing blood to the front part of the heart, including the septum and the left ventricle. The LAD is often referred to as the "widowmaker" artery because blockage of this artery can lead to severe myocardial infarction, which is often fatal.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Left circumflex artery: This artery supplies the lateral and posterior walls of the left ventricle but does not supply the anterior interventricular septum.

 

Option B. Left marginal artery: This artery branches off the circumflex artery and supplies the left ventricle's lateral wall, but it does not supply the interventricular septum.

 

Option D. Posterior interventricular artery: This artery supplies the posterior third of the interventricular septum but not the anterior portion. It runs in the posterior interventricular groove.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The anterior interventricular artery (LAD) supplies the anterior two-thirds of the interventricular septum and is critical for heart function, making it a key vessel in coronary circulation.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the Papez circuit? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Posterior thalamic nuclei

 

Explanation:


The Papez circuit is a neural pathway within the limbic system that plays a crucial role in memory formation and emotional processing. This circuit forms a closed loop that includes the hippocampus, fornix, mammillary bodies, mammillothalamic tract, anterior thalamic nuclei, cingulate gyrus, and back to the hippocampus via the entorhinal cortex. The posterior thalamic nuclei are not components of this circuit - instead, it's the anterior thalamic nuclei that participate in the Papez pathway.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. Hippocampus - This is a key component of the Papez circuit. The hippocampus is essential for memory formation and connects to the mammillary bodies via the fornix, forming a critical segment of the circuit.
  • Option b. Mammillary bodies - These are definite components of the Papez circuit. Located in the hypothalamus, the mammillary bodies receive input from the hippocampus and project to the anterior thalamic nuclei via the mammillothalamic tract.
  • Option c. Cingulate gyrus - This is an integral component of the Papez circuit. The cingulate gyrus receives projections from the anterior thalamic nuclei and connects back to the hippocampus, completing the circuit.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Papez circuit is a fundamental limbic pathway for emotional processing and memory formation that interconnects the hippocampus, mammillary bodies, and cingulate gyrus, but excludes the posterior thalamic nuclei.

questions.text: What is the most frequent cause of normocalcemic tetany? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Alkalosis

 

Explanation:

 

Alkalosis is the most frequent cause of normocalcemic tetany. This occurs because alkalosis decreases the ionized fraction of calcium in the blood without affecting total calcium levels. During alkalosis, more calcium becomes bound to plasma proteins (particularly albumin), reducing the physiologically active ionized calcium. Since only the ionized calcium is physiologically active, this reduction leads to tetany despite normal total calcium levels.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B. Acidosis - Acidosis actually increases ionized calcium by reducing protein binding of calcium, which would protect against tetany rather than cause it.
  • Option C. Hypermagnesemia - Elevated magnesium levels typically cause CNS depression and hyporeflexia rather than tetany. Hypermagnesemia would not be expected to cause tetany with normal calcium levels.
  • Option D. Hypophosphatemia - While hypophosphatemia can affect calcium metabolism, it typically causes hypercalcemia rather than normocalcemia. It is not a frequent cause of normocalcemic tetany.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alkalosis causes normocalcemic tetany by decreasing ionized calcium through increased protein binding, despite normal total calcium levels in the blood.

questions.text: A male infant presents with recurrent infections. Laboratory examination shows reduced B-cells and low levels of different antibodies. There is a normal reaction to environmental antigens on the skin. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bruton's agammaglobulinemia

 

Bruton's agammaglobulinemia is an X-linked recessive disorder characterized by a defect in B-cell tyrosine kinase (BTK), resulting in a severe reduction or absence of B lymphocytes and all immunoglobulin isotypes. This condition primarily affects male infants who present with recurrent bacterial infections after 6 months of age when maternal antibodies wane. The normal reaction to environmental antigens on the skin indicates intact T-cell immunity, which is characteristic of Bruton's agammaglobulinemia where only B-cell function is affected.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. DiGeorge syndrome: Incorrect. DiGeorge syndrome is a T-cell problem characterized by thymic hypoplasia, resulting in defective T-cell immunity. Patients would show abnormal reactions to environmental antigens on the skin due to impaired T-cell function. Additionally, patients typically present with hypocalcemia due to parathyroid issues, cardiac defects, and characteristic facial features.

 

Option C. Common variable immunodeficiency (CVID): Incorrect. While CVID also affects B cells, it typically presents later in life (usually after puberty) and is characterized by hyperplastic lymph nodes and tonsils. In CVID, B cells are present but do not function properly, which differs from the reduced B-cell numbers .

 

Option D. Selective IgA deficiency: Incorrect. Selective IgA deficiency is the most common immunoglobulin deficiency but involves only IgA. Patients have normal B-cell counts and normal levels of other immunoglobulins. It is associated with increased risk of respiratory and GI infections but typically less severe than what would be expected with Bruton's agammaglobulinemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bruton's agammaglobulinemia is an X-linked recessive disorder characterized by absent B cells, low or absent immunoglobulins of all classes, and normal T-cell function, resulting in recurrent bacterial infections in male infants.

choices.text: A - Cortisol B - Aldosterone C - Androgens D - Epinephrine
A - Aldosterone B - Cortisol C - Androgens D - Epinephrine
A - Epinephrine B - Cortisol C - Aldosterone D - Androgens
A - Aldosterone B - Epinephrine C - Androgens D - Cortisol

questions.text: Which hormones are produced from these zones? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A - Aldosterone B - Cortisol C - Androgens D - Epinephrine

 

Explanation:

 

The adrenal gland, located on top of the kidneys, consists of the adrenal cortex and the adrenal medulla. The cortex is further divided into three zones: the zona glomerulosa, zona fasciculata, and zona reticularis. These zones are responsible for producing different types of hormones, remembered by the mnemonic "GFR."

 

  • Zona Glomerulosa (A): This outermost layer is responsible for producing mineralocorticoids, the most important being Aldosterone. Aldosterone plays a critical role in regulating sodium and potassium balance in the body.
  • Zona Fasciculata (B): The middle layer produces glucocorticoids, primarily Cortisol. Cortisol is involved in stress response, metabolism regulation, and immune function.
  • Zona Reticularis (C): The innermost cortical layer produces androgens, specifically DHEA (Dehydroepiandrosterone), which is a precursor to sex steroids like testosterone and estrogen.
  • Adrenal Medulla (D): The medulla produces catecholamines, primarily Epinephrine (adrenaline), which is crucial for the fight-or-flight response.

 

Educational Objective:


The adrenal cortex is divided into three zones—zona glomerulosa, zona fasciculata, and zona reticularis—which produce aldosterone, cortisol, and androgens, respectively. The adrenal medulla produces catecholamines, primarily epinephrine

choices.text: FTA-ABS- Fluorescent Treponemal Antibody Absorption test

questions.text: What is the investigation of choice for neurosyphilis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Venereal disease research laboratory (VDRL) test

 

The investigation of choice for neurosyphilis is VDRL.

 

The CSF-VDRL test is highly specific and, when reactive, is considered diagnostic of neurosyphilis.

 

Involvement of the CNS in syphilis is detected by examination of CSF for:

 

  • Mononuclear pleocytosis (>5 white blood cells/uL).
  • Increased protein concentration (>45 mg/dL).
  • CSF VDRL reactivity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. FTA-ABS (Fluorescent Treponemal Antibody Absorption test): This test is highly sensitive for detecting the presence of antibodies to Treponema pallidum and is used to confirm a syphilis infection but is not specific for neurosyphilis as it can be positive due to past or present infection anywhere in the body.

 

Option C. RPR (Rapid Plasma Reagin test): Similar to VDRL, used as a screening test for syphilis based on the detection of non-treponemal antibodies indicative of an active infection, but not specific for neurosyphilis.

 

Option D. TPI (Treponema pallidum immobilization test): This is an older, highly specific test that is not commonly used today.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The CSF-VDRL test, despite its low sensitivity, remains the gold standard for the diagnosis of neurosyphilis due to its high specificity when positive. It is crucial in the diagnostic process for patients with suspected syphilis infection of the central nervous system, helping guide appropriate treatment and management.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cutaneous manifestation of Dermatomyositis?  (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gorlin Sign

 

  • Gorlin sign is the ability of a person to touch the tip of their nose with their tongue.

 

 

  • This sign is a marker of generalized connective tissue laxity {Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome (EDS)}
  • Gorlin Sign is not a cutaneous manifestation of dermatomyositis. 

 

Dermatomyositis

 

  • The cutaneous manifestations of dermatomyositis include several characteristic signs, such as Gottron's papules (violaceous flat-topped papules over the knuckles), 
  • Gottron's sign (violaceous macular erythema over joints), 
  • Heliotrope rash (violaceous discoloration of the eyelids with edema), 
  • Mechanic's hands (hyperkeratotic fissuring involving tips and sides of digits), 

 

Distribution-based Dermatomyositis signs, including the 

 

  • Shawl sign (erythema over the upper back and shoulders), 
  • V-sign (erythema over the anterior chest)
  • Holster sign (erythema on the lateral aspect of the thighs).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Shawl Sign:

 

  • This is a genuine manifestation of dermatomyositis, characterized by erythema over the upper back, shoulders, and posterior neck in a shawl-like distribution.

 

 

Option B. Heliotrope Rash:

 

  • This is a classic cutaneous feature of dermatomyositis. 
  • It presents as violaceous (lilac/purple) discoloration with edema of the periorbital region, named after the heliotrope flower, which has a similar violet color.

 

 

Option C. Mechanic's Hands:

 

  • This is a characteristic finding in dermatomyositis, characterized by hyperkeratotic fissuring involving the tips and sides of digits. 

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Dermatomyositis has several pathognomonic cutaneous manifestations, including Gottron's papules/sign, heliotrope rash, mechanic's hands, and distribution-specific patterns like the Shawl sign, V-sign, and Holster sign, but Gorlin sign is not among them.

questions.text: The axillary artery is divided into three parts by?(NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer. B. Pectoralis minor

 

Explanation: 

 

The axillary artery is divided into three distinct parts by the pectoralis minor muscle. This key muscle of the axillary region serves as an important anatomical landmark that helps segment the axillary artery for descriptive purposes. Each part of the axillary artery gives specific branches: the first part (proximal to pectoralis minor) gives the superior thoracic artery; the second part (behind pectoralis minor) gives the thoracoacromial and lateral thoracic arteries; and the third part (distal to pectoralis minor) gives the anterior circumflex humeral, posterior circumflex humeral, and subscapular arteries.

 

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Scalenus anterior - This muscle divides the subclavian artery into three parts, not the axillary artery. The subclavian artery becomes the axillary artery as it crosses the outer border of the first rib.
  • Option C. Teres minor - This muscle forms part of the rotator cuff and is related to the posterior wall of the axilla. It doesn't divide the axillary artery but forms part of the boundary of the quadrangular space.
  • Option D. Teres major - This muscle forms the lower boundary of the posterior wall of the axilla. The axillary artery ends at the lower border of teres major to become the brachial artery, but teres major doesn't divide the axillary artery into parts.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Pectoralis minor is the key muscle that divides the axillary artery into three parts, with each part giving rise to specific branches that supply the pectoral region and upper limb.

questions.text: A young male presents with suspected poisoning and has pin-point pupils. Which of the following can be the poison.  (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Opioid
 

 

Educational objective :

 

Pin-point pupils are a classic sign of opioid intoxication and are crucial for identifying opioid overdose in clinical settings. Opioids act by stimulating mu-receptors, leading to reduced sympathetic tone in the eye, which results in constricted pupils.

questions.text: A child came with malnutrition and follicular hyperkeratotic skin lesions. There was a deficiency of Vitamin A and Essential Fatty Acids. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Phrynoderma

 

Phrynoderma, also known as "toad skin," is a type of dermatosis characterized by hyperkeratotic papules that primarily occur over the extensor surfaces such as the elbows and knees. This condition is closely associated with nutritional deficiencies, particularly of Vitamin A and essential fatty acids. In severe cases, deficiencies in other vitamins like Vitamin B complex, Vitamin C, and Vitamin E have also been observed to contribute to this condition.

 

The presentation of follicular hyperkeratotic lesions in a malnourished child, along with documented deficiencies of Vitamin A and essential fatty acids, strongly points to phrynoderma. Recognizing this characteristic presentation is crucial in diagnosing and treating the condition effectively.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Scurvy: Scurvy is caused by a deficiency of Vitamin C and is characterized by symptoms such as bleeding gums, bruising, and petechiae, but it does not typically cause follicular hyperkeratotic lesions. Therefore, this is not the correct diagnosis.

 

Option C. Keratosis pilaris: This is a common, benign condition that presents with rough, small, acne-like bumps, typically on the arms, thighs, cheeks, and buttocks. It is not associated with the nutritional deficiencies described in the question, making it an unlikely diagnosis here.

 

Option D. Keratosis follicularis (Darier's disease): This is a genetic skin disorder characterized by greasy, warty papules and plaques in seborrheic areas like the scalp, forehead, upper arms, chest, and back. It is not associated with vitamin deficiencies or malnutrition, which makes it an in Ans.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phrynoderma is associated with malnutrition and deficiencies in Vitamin A and essential fatty acids, and it presents with follicular hyperkeratotic skin lesions, particularly over the elbows and knees.

questions.text: Which congenital heart disease is most commonly associated with Down's Syndrome? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Atrioventricular Septal Defect (AVSD)

 

Explanation: 

 

Atrioventricular Septal Defect (AVSD), also known as endocardial cushion defect or atrioventricular canal defect, is the most commonly associated congenital heart defect in Down syndrome (Trisomy 21). About 40-60% of children with Down syndrome have congenital heart disease, and AVSD is the most specific cardiac anomaly, accounting for approximately 30-40% of these cardiac defects. AVSD occurs due to failure of proper development of the endocardial cushions, which are essential for the formation of the lower portion of the atrial septum, the upper portion of the ventricular septum, and the mitral and tricuspid valves.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA) - Incorrect. While PDA can occur in Down syndrome, it is not the most common or specific cardiac defect associated with the condition. PDA represents failure of the fetal connection between the aorta and pulmonary artery to close after birth.

 

Option B. Atrial Septal Defect (ASD) - Incorrect. Ostium secundum ASD is common in Down syndrome but not as specific or prevalent as AVSD. The ostium primum type of ASD is actually part of the AVSD spectrum.

 

Option C. Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) - Incorrect. TOF occurs in approximately 6-8% of Down syndrome patients with cardiac defects but is not the most common cardiac anomaly in this population. TOF is more commonly associated with 22q11 deletion syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atrioventricular Septal Defect (AVSD) is the most common and specific congenital heart defect in Down syndrome, affecting approximately 30-40% of patients with cardiac anomalies due to abnormal development of the endocardial cushions.

choices.text: Peak systolic velocity in the fetal middle cerebral artery (MCA)

questions.text: A 29-year-old pregnant woman at 28 weeks of gestation is undergoing routine obstetric evaluation. She has a history of Rh incompatibility, and recent laboratory results show the presence of elevated maternal anti-D antibody titers. The obstetrician is concerned about possible fetal anemia. Which of the following methods is most commonly used to assess fetal anemia in this situation? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Peak systolic velocity in the fetal middle cerebral artery (MCA)

 

Explanation:

 

Fetal anemia in Rh-incompatible pregnancies is primarily assessed using Doppler ultrasound of the fetal middle cerebral artery (MCA). The peak systolic velocity (PSV) of the MCA increases in response to anemia due to a brain-sparing effect, where blood flow is redistributed to essential organs like the brain.

 

  • When maternal anti-D titers are elevated, the fetus is monitored using MCA Doppler ultrasonography.
  • If the MCA-PSV is >1.5 multiples of the median (MoM) for gestational age, this suggests moderate-to-severe fetal anemia.
  • If significant anemia is suspected, cordocentesis (cord blood sampling) may be performed for direct measurement of fetal hemoglobin levels and possible intrauterine transfusion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cord blood sampling (Cordocentesis):

 

  • This is the gold standard for diagnosing fetal anemia but is an invasive procedure associated with risks like preterm labor and fetal loss. It is only performed when MCA Doppler findings suggest severe anemia.

 

Option B. Chorionic villus sampling (CVS):

 

  • This is used primarily for chromosomal and genetic analysis in the first trimester.
  • It has no role in detecting fetal anemia.

 

Option D. Umbilical artery Doppler:

 

  • This is used in cases of intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR) to assess placental insufficiency.
  • It is not useful for detecting fetal anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The peak systolic velocity of the fetal middle cerebral artery (MCA-PSV) is the most commonly used non-invasive method to assess fetal anemia in cases of Rh incompatibility. A value greater than 1.5 MoM indicates moderate-to-severe anemia, warranting further invasive testing like cordocentesis.

questions.text: 3-point bony relationship is maintained in which fracture?(INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Supracondylar humerus fracture

 

THREE POINT BONY LANDMARKS IN ELBOW

 

  • Tips of medial and lateral epicondyles and olecranon
  • Form isosceles triangle with elbow in 90° flexion
  • Lie transversely in straight line in elbow extension

 

 

  • Three-point bony relationship is not disturbed in fracture supracondylar humerus as the fracture occurs above the level of these bony landmarks.
  • With disturbed (increased) intercondylar distance: 
    • Fracture lateral epicondyle and condyle
    • Fracture medial epicondyle and condyle
    • Fracture intercondylar humerus.
  • With maintained intercondylar distance: 
    • Fracture olecranon (i.e. upper end ulna)
    • Elbow dislocation (classical example)
  • Waeak posterior capsule may disrupt three-point bony relation by promoting subluxation or dislocations of elbow.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Elbow dislocation. In elbow dislocation, the intercondylar distance is maintained but the three-point bony relationship is disturbed.

 

Option C. Intercondylar humerus fracture. In this fracture, the intercondylar distance is disturbed i.e., increased, so is the three-point bony relationship.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The three-point bony relationship of the elbow is maintained only in the supracondylar humerus fracture because this fracture occurs above the bony landmarks associated with the relation.
